Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Prevailing sentiment: Tipping culture is seen as overgrown and pressured, especially due to tablet checkout prompts and requests in contexts with little or no service. Many feel uncomfortable being asked, dislike pre-service tipping prompts, and want tipping to return to a voluntary expression of appreciation rather than an expectation.

  • Compensation and fairness: Strong support for employers paying a livable base wage (at least the standard minimum, with several calling for around $15/hour) so workers don’t rely on tips. Many would abolish tipping entirely if wages were raised; others would keep tipping as a bonus for exceptional service. Several call out the subminimum tipped wage as unjust.

  • Alternatives to traditional tipping:

  • Replace tipping with a built-in service charge (often suggested around 10%) or integrate it into menu prices.
  • Make tipping optional on top of a service charge, not pre-printed on the bill.

  • Adopt practices seen in Europe or Japan where tipping is minimal or embedded.

  • Scope and norms:

  • Limit tipping primarily to full-service restaurants and clear service work (serving, bussing), not for pickup, drive-thru, fast food, coffee counters, or self-service.

  • Do not prompt for tips before service is delivered.

  • How to tip when it remains:

  • Tie tips to quality of service; many endorse tipping generously for good service and withholding or reducing for poor service.
  • Mixed views on calculation: most prefer percentages; a minority prefer fixed amounts or standardized guidance. One view suggests standardizing tip levels to avoid manipulation or confusion.

  • A few suggest not taxing tips.

  • System and UX improvements:

  • Make “no tip” or “custom tip” easy to find on POS screens; avoid coercive default percentages.
  • Show tipping options only when a clear service has been provided.

  • Some propose small thank-you gestures (notes, coupons) to acknowledge tips.

  • Minority views:

  • A small portion support mandatory tipping or fixed service charges everywhere, or believe patrons should not use tipped services if they can’t tip.

  • A few are strongly pro-tipping as an incentive and always tip at least 20%.

  • Underlying themes:

  • Concern about employer cost-shifting onto customers, tip inflation, and unclear expectations.
  • Recognition that, under current U.S. norms, tips remain essential for many workers’ income, even among those who want long-term structural change.

Summary B

Summary of Comments on the Tipping System

The comments reveal widespread dissatisfaction with the current tipping system, with many participants expressing frustration about its expansion beyond traditional service contexts. A significant portion of respondents feel that tipping has become excessive, with requests appearing in situations where they previously weren't expected, such as simple transactions or self-service pickups.

The most common theme throughout the responses is the belief that employers should pay livable wages rather than relying on customers to supplement worker income through tips. Many participants view the current system as a way for businesses to shift compensation responsibilities onto consumers. Several respondents specifically mentioned that service workers often depend heavily on tips due to inadequate base wages, creating an unfair dynamic for both workers and customers.

Regarding improvements, suggestions varied but centered on a few key approaches:

  • Complete elimination: Multiple participants favor abolishing the tipping system entirely, with some noting that the United States is unique in its heavy reliance on tipping compared to other countries, particularly Europe.

  • Living wage implementation: The most frequently mentioned solution involves requiring businesses to pay employees fair, livable wages, thereby reducing or eliminating the need for tips.

  • Optional rather than mandatory: Several respondents emphasized that tipping should be voluntary and based on service quality, not an expected or forced addition to every transaction.

  • Alternative approaches: Some creative suggestions included implementing fixed tip amounts rather than percentages, adding service charges to bills instead of tips, or creating incentive systems where tips provide mutual benefits (such as thank-you notes or future discounts).

While a minority of participants expressed support for tipping as a way to reward good service or help workers earn more, the overall sentiment leans heavily toward reform. Most respondents agree that when tipping does occur, it should be genuinely optional and merit-based, not a social obligation or substitute for proper wages.

[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I am skewed towards thinking tipping is not a good thing. It is very variable and makes people pay more for their already expensive food or whatever. I would honestly just get rid of it outright or try to tone it down to only fine dining places.
